awd_titl_txt: NRI: FND: COLLAB: A Foundational Approach to Muscle Actuators that Lowers Barriers to Muscle-Powered Robotics Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Robotics Initiative (NRI) project will promote the progress of science and advance the national prosperity by developing a foundational approach towards muscle-powered machines that move using biomimetic muscle actuators. Biomimetic muscle actuators, or robot muscles, are actuators that closely mimic the properties of biological muscles in nature. A common set of challenges in actuator selection and design, and modeling and controlling behaviors and properties emerge among different muscle actuators. This award supports identifying and unifying modeling, control, and design strategies that would lower the barrier to muscle-powered robotics research.  A significant effort to de-risk robot muscles for designers is the creation of a robot muscles toolkit, an accessible software and hardware toolkit for designing muscle-powered machines and for democratizing the development and proliferation of these technologies at a broad scale. Design challenges and competitions will spur the interests and community building for those interested in robot muscles across all ages and experiences, from K-12 to college students and researchers.  Local arrangements for outreach in the San Diego and Greater Boston Area communities are planned for stirring interest in robotics for underrepresented minorities.

A novel, data-driven process and structure for parameterizing a common set of biomimetic features that define muscle actuation will be developed in order to anchor modeling, control, and design strategies across a so-called performance and configuration space. These methods can be employed across muscle types and generalize beyond currently available muscle actuators. There is a strategy for muscle selection over multi-dimensional performance criteria that incorporates both empirical data and physics models. Design strategies for muscle configurations for amplification along these performance dimensions, generalizable across muscles, will be investigated. New technologies will be able to be easily added into this framework to perform quantitative comparison studies without replication of gold standard actuators.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
Overall, this project has focused on expanding the performance and diversity of muscle-like actuators. We have explored several classes of actuators and evaluated them in terms of their performance, ability to integrate within bioinspired, soft, and small robots, and described them subject to metrics of relevance to the soft robotics community. Throughout the project we have also aimed to integrate our muscle-like actuators into various soft and/or small robot systems. This has led to breakthroughs with the use of electrically-driven artificial muscles to drive and control fluidic soft actuators – a ubiquitous form of actuation for soft robots, but a form of actuation that typically requires bulk, rigid, and inefficient power and control systems. 

 

One area we have focused on is the improvement of dielectric elastomer actuators (DEAs). DEAs operate electrostatically based on the application of high electric fields to electrodes on elastomeric films. We have made progress on materials and processing methods to make these devices more practical and easier to construct. The biggest breakthrough in this project has involved the use of a particular form of DEAs – “rolled” DEAs – for interacting with fluidic channels. The first use is as valves for control of fluidic mechanisms. Fluidic actuators are the most common form of artificial muscles in soft robotics, but pressure generation and storage devices are most often made from rigid materials and utilize electromechanical drivers (e.g., solenoid valves). We have created a new class of valves that are primarily soft by using DEAs to impinge upon a fluidic channel, showing that the DEAs can control the channel deformation, and thus the pressure-flow characteristics. This was used as the basis for the first soft fluidic actuator control demonstrations using another soft actuator as the driving mechanism. Finally, we were able to use these DEA valves in a closed-loop control system where a human operator wearing a soft sensor on their finger was able to control the motion of a soft actuator by modulating the DEA valve response in proportion to the sensed motion of the finger. 

 

Our use of DEAs for soft actuator control was expanded from valves to pumps. We developed the first soft peristaltic DEA pump and used that to directly power and control a variety of soft fluidic actuators. This represent a significant step towards entirely electronic control of soft actuators, even if those actuators are fluid-driven. Furthermore, we expect a variety of additional uses for this pump, for example implantable devices moving blood or dispensing drugs. 

 

Finally, we continued to investigate improvements on other actuator types including piezoelectric bending actuators. We also explored the integration of such actuators into a variety of mechanisms including small-scale bioinspired robots and biomedical devices such as microsurgical tools. 

 


Last Modified: 11/11/2022
Modified by: Robert Wood
